Graphical abstract The hydroformylation of highly substituted alkyl olefins was efficiently performed, with use of rhodium(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite catalysts, containing different ether substituents at the 2′-binaphthyl position (OMe, OBn, OCHPh2 and OAdamantyl). A systematic kinetic study, carried out for hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate, has shown a significant influence of the ligand’s OR group in the performance of the rhodium catalysts, with Rh(I)/tris[2′-benzyloxy-1,1′-binaphthyl-2-yl]phosphite catalytic system (Rh(I)/L2-OBn) achieving the highest chemoselectivity for aldehydes, and regioselectivity for C-5 formyl products. This catalytic system was further applied to the hydroformylation of encumbered CC double bonds of natural products, namely oleic acid methyl ester, (−)-isopulegol benzyl ether and 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene, obtaining high catalytic activity, chemo-, regio- and diastereoselectivity, under relatively mild reaction conditions. Keywords Rhodium/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite Hydroformylation Substituted alkyl olefins Terpenes Steroids 1 Introduction Discovered by Roelen [1], the hydroformylation reaction (oxo process), catalysed by transition-metal complexes, is currently considered one the most relevant tools to promote the one-step transformation of simple olefins into aldehydes, being the largest scale industrial method of homogeneous catalysis [2] with multiple applications in bulk chemical industry [3], as well as in fine chemical synthesis [4,5]. Along decades, there has been huge interest in the development of catalytic hydroformylation processes to promote the introduction of formyl groups into functionalized substrates leading to high value products [6–8], namely unsaturated esters [9], steroids[10] and terpene derivatives [11]. The relevance of such compounds relies on the fact that they are naturally occurring substances with high abundance, which can be used for the development of biologically active compounds [12], drugs [13], cosmetics [14] and biodiesel [15,16]. However, the main difficulties are related to low reactivity of substituted and internal double CC bonds in these substrates. Consequently, hard reaction conditions are often required, and most catalysts present low to moderate activity and selectivity [17,18]. In the 1990’s, a peculiar effect was found with the use of bulky aryl monophosphites [19–21], whose rhodium complexes led to very high rates, chemo- and regioselectivities in the hydroformylation of disubstituted and internal olefins, allowing the possibility of using milder reaction conditions. Since then, multiple applications have been reported regarding the use of this type of rhodium catalysts. For example, Rh(I)/tris-(2-tert-butyl-phenyl)phosphite catalyst has been reported as an active and selective system to promote the hydroformylation of mono [22,23] and diterpenes [24], the diastereoselective hydroformylation of steroid molecules [10], as well as tandem hydroformylation–acetalization of bicyclic monoterpenes [25] Despite the latest advances [5,26,27], the development of active and selective Rh(I)/phosphorus catalysts is still a great challenge in order to expand the applications of catalytic hydroformylation to industrial processes. Recently, some of us reported the synthesis of a new class of bulky tris-binaphthyl monophosphite ligands [28,29], whose metal complexes showed high activity in the hydroformylation of disubstituted aryl olefins and also in other catalytic reactions [30,31]. Encouraged by the challenge of promoting the hydroformylation of natural products and considering our interest in the applications of catalytic hydroformylation as a tool for the development of value added products, herein we report the use of Rh(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite catalysts to promote the hydroformylation of sterically hindered alkyl olefins, such as methyl non-3-enoate, methyl oleate, (−)-isopulegol benzyl ether and 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instruments The reagents methyl non-3-enoate (1) (≥96%), methyl oleate (4) (≥99%), dicarbonyl(acetylacetonate) rhodium(I) (≥98%), benzyl bromide (≥98%), (R)- and (S)-BINOL (99%) and were acquired from Sigma–Aldrich and used without further purifications. CO and H2 with 99.997% and 99.95% purities, respectively, were purchased from Praxair. (−)-Isopulegol was obtained from a mixture of (−)-isopulegol and (+)-neoisopulegol, purchased from Firmenich. All solvents were dried and purified by standard methods [32]. Thin layer chromatography (TLC) was performed on Merck silica gel 60 TLC-plates with P254. Gas chromatography analysis was carried out in a HP-Agilent 6890 chromatographer, equipped with ionization detector (FID) and with HP-5 column, non-polar (5% diphenyl, 95% dimethylpolysiloxane, (30m×0.32mm). GC–MS spectra were obtained in a Hewlett-Packard 5973 MSD spectrometer, using EI (70eV), coupled to a Hewlett-Packard Agilent 6890 chromatograph, equipped with a HP-5 MS column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). 1H, 13C and 31P NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl3 on a Bruker Avance III spectrometer, and a Bruker DRX-400 spectrometer, both operating at 400MHz for 1H, 100MHz for 13C and 161MHz for 31P. Chemical shifts are expressed in ppm, relatively to an internal standard of TMS, for 1H and 13C, and to a solution of phosphoric acid (85%) as external standard for 31P spectra. FTIR spectra (with 1cm−1 spectral resolution) were collected on a ThermoNicolet IR300 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer, equipped with a deuterated triglycine sulfate (DTGS) detector and a Ge/KBr beam splitter, using KBr pellets. 2.2 Synthesis of ligands and substrates The phosphite ligands L1-OMe, L2-OBn, L3-OAd, L4-OCHPh2 were synthesized according to our recently optimised procedure, with spectroscopic data (1H, 13C, 31P NMR and HRMS-ESI) being in agreement with that previously reported [28,29]. Tris(orto-tert-butylphenyl) phosphite (P(O-o- t BuC6H4)3) was synthesized by following a literature procedure [19]. (−)-Isopulegol benzyl ether (5) was prepared by etherification of (−)-isopulegol with benzyl bromide (see Supporting information (SI) for details of its synthesis and characterization). The steroid derivative 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene (6) [33,34] was gently provided by A. F. Peixoto, from Coimbra Catalysis & Fine Chemistry Laboratory. 2.3 General procedure of Rh(I)/monophosphite-catalysed hydroformylation A stainless steel autoclave, containing a 40mL glass vessel, was charged with the monophosphite ligand. Then, the rhodium precursor [Rh(acac)(CO)2], dissolved in toluene, was added via cannula (see relative amounts, for each experiment, in Tables 1 and 2 ). The system was purged with three cycles of vacuum and an equimolar mixture of CO/H2 (syngas). The autoclave was pressurised with syngas (30bar), the temperature was set to 80°C and the mixture was magnetically stirred for 1h (external stirring rate of 450rpm). After this incubation period, the autoclave was slowly depressurised and the substrate, dissolved in toluene, was introduced through the inlet cannula (see relative amounts, for each experiment, in Tables 1 and 2). Then, the autoclave was pressurised with CO/H2 (25bar) and the temperature was set on the desired value. Reaction kinetics was followed by taking and analysing GC aliquots of the reaction mixture at regular intervals. At the end, the autoclave was cooled, slowly depressurised and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. Identification and characterisation of products were performed by GC–MS, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy. Conversions, chemo-, regio- and diasteroselectivity were determined by GC analysis. 2.4 Coordination studies of [Rh(acac)(CO)(phosphite)] complexes in solution A dried Sclenck tube was charged with [Rh(acac)(CO)2] (2.6mg, 0.01mmol) and each monophosphite ligand L1-OMe, L2-OBn, L3-OAd or L4-OCHPh2 (0.01mmol), under a nitrogen atmosphere. The solids were dissolved in CDCl3 (0.5mL), and the mixture was subjected to magnetic stirring for 5–30min, at 25°C. Then, 31P NMR spectra of the resulting solutions were registered. Competitive reactions were carried out, by addition of equimolar amounts of two different monophosphite ligands to [Rh(acac)(CO)2], and by adding a monophosphite ligand to a different Rh/phosphite complex solution. 2.5 HP NMR studies of [RhH(CO)(phosphite)] complexes in solution High-pressure NMR experiments (HPNMR), performed at the Department of Physical and Inorganic Chemistry of University Rovira i Virgili—Tarragona, were carried out in a 10mm-diameter sapphire tube with a titanium cap equipped with a Teflon/polycarbonate protection, using the following conditions: [Rh(acac)(CO)2] (2.6mg, 0.01mmol), L2-OBn (37.0mg, 0.032mmol), toluene-d8 (1mL), 36bar syngas, 80°C, 24h). In order to observe the formation of Rh/hydride species, 1H NMR was carried out at −40°C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate Considering the interest in promoting the hydroformylation of unsaturated methyl esters containing internal CC double bonds, aiming at their transformation into the corresponding aldehydes, the Rh(I)/monophosphite catalysts were first applied to the hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate (1). In order to appraise the effects of the ligand’s structure on the activity and selectivity of the rhodium(I) catalytic systems, a set of four tris-binaphthyl monophosphites [28,29] containing different ether (−OR) appendices, L1-OMe, L2-OBn, L3-OAd and L4-OCHPh2, were evaluated as ligands (Fig. 1 ). In a typical reaction, the autoclave was charged with the appropriate amounts of phosphite ligand, [Rh(acac)(CO)2] (in a 3:1 ratio) and toluene as solvent. The reactor was then pressurised with an equimolar mixture of CO/H2 (30bar), and the mixture was stirred for 1h, at 80°C. After this incubation period, methyl non-3-enoate (1), dissolved in toluene, was added via cannula, and the reaction was conducted at 60°C and 25bar CO/H2, under magnetic stirring. The reaction’s progress along 8h was followed by GC analysis of aliquots taken at regular intervals from the reaction mixture (Fig. 2 ). As clearly shown in Fig. 2, distinct profiles were obtained with each different Rh(I)/monophosphite catalytic system. Rh(I)/L1-OMe showed a moderate catalytic performance, with the substrate conversion encompassing the parallel formation of aldehydes and double-bond isomers (Fig. 2a). An identical behaviour was observed with Rh(I)/L4-OCHPh2 catalyst, also with similar amounts of aldehydes and double-bond isomers being formed over time, leading to low chemoselectivity (Fig. 2b), but with lower conversion than that obtained with the previous system. When compared with the former systems, the hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate (1) using Rh(I)/L3-OAd as catalyst, presents noticeable changes, being the one that achieved the highest conversion. In this particular case, the percentage of aldehydes was similar to that of isomerisation products, during the first 2h (ca. 30%). However, after this period, the consumption of substrate (and double-bond isomers) was accompanied by a substantial increase on the percentage of aldehydes (Fig. 2c). Remarkably, the use of L2-OBn as ligand resulted in the most efficient Rh(I) catalytic system, providing high conversions, and advantageously displaying the highest chemoselectivity for aldehydes, while the percentage of double-bond isomers was <10%, practically constant during the reaction course (Fig. 2d). The comparative results at 8h reaction are presented in Table 1. The Rh(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite systems were able to efficiently catalyse the hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate, with TON's being significantly influenced by the—OR groups at the 2′-binaphthyl positions of the bulky phosphite ligand (L3-OAd > L2-OBn> L1-OMe>> L4-OCHPh2) (Table 1, entries 1–4). In the absence of monophosphite ligand, the non-modified Rh(I) catalyst provided only 36% of aldehydes (2), while olefin isomers (3) were formed in up to 56% (Table 1, entry 5). In order to establish a comparison with a related monophosphite ligand, the widely studied catalytic system Rh(I)/tris(orto-tert-butylphenyl) phosphite [19] was evaluated in the same reaction, providing 75% conversion in 8h, with 73% selectivity for aldehydes, under the same reactions conditions (Table 1, entry 6). Therefore, Rh(I)/L2-OBn catalyst was shown to be more active and selective than the classic Rh/bulky monophosphite catalytic system (Table 1, entries 2 and 6). The products' identification was carried out by NMR and GC–MS analysis of crude mixtures. 1H NMR spectra revealed, in all cases, the presence of two doublets, at δ =9.47ppm (major) and δ =9.36ppm (minor), with J =1.2Hz and 3.2Hz, respectively, typical of formyl protons resonance. A triplet at 0.70ppm (J =6.8Hz), assigned to the methyl protons of the terminal CH3 group, indicates the presence of internal formyl groups, resulting from the hydroformylation of internal CC bonds. The formation of both aldehydes was corroborated by two 13C NMR signals at δ =202.2ppm and 203.6ppm. GC–MS analysis further confirmed the formation of two aldehydes, presenting a major and a minor peak. Surprisingly, the MS fragmentation patterns of the major and minor signals were indicative of the aldehydes containing the formyl groups at C5 and C4 positions, respectively, while the expected C3-formyl aldehyde is not formed as main product, suggesting that hydroformylation occurs via a prior double-bond isomerisation to C-4 position of the alkyl chain. In accordance to the well-established mechanism of Rh-catalysed hydroformylation of internal alkyl olefins [35,36], after coordination/insertion into rhodium-hydride, the Rh(I) intermediate undergoes β-elimination, leading to double-bond isomerisation. In this particular case, the rhodium hydride complex coordinated to the olefin at C-4, may be stabilised by a 6-member ring intermediate [37] (Scheme 1 ), which avoids further isomerisation. Finally, subsequent CO and H2 insertions result in the formation of aldehydes 2a and 2b. The regioselectivity for aldehyde 2a, obtained with the Rh(I)/monophosphite catalytic systems varied in the range of 56% (with L3-OAd) to 69% (with L2-OBn). But, above all, the ether—OR appendices at the monophosphite ligand showed a pronounced effect on the catalytic activity and chemoselectivity of the Rh(I) catalysts in hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate, where Rh(I)/L2-OBn was shown to be the one that combines high activity with the highest selectivity for aldehydes. 3.2 Rhodium(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite complexes The relative reactivity of phosphite ligands L1-OMe, L2-OBn, L3-OAd and L4-OCHPh2 toward complexation with Rh(I) was accessed by solution 31P NMR spectroscopy. In a typical experiment, the rhodium(I) precursor [Rh(acac)(CO)2] and each tris-binaphthyl monophosphite were dissolved in CDCl3, under a N2 atmosphere, with the mixture being stirred for 5–30min, at 25°C. At the end, 31P NMR spectra of the resulting solutions were registered. In agreement with our previous observations [29], the complexation between equimolar amounts of [Rh(acac)(CO)2] and monophosphite ligands L1-OMe, L2-OBn or L3-OAd readily occurs in 5min, all resulting in the formation of a major species assigned to P-Rh coordination mode (31P doublet in the range 120–125ppm with 1 J (103Rh–31P)=289–292Hz) and a minor one (≤10%) assigned to a heterobidentate P,O-Rh coordination mode (31P doublet in the range 130–133ppm with 1 J (103Rh–31P)=260–265Hz). The 31P NMR spectrum obtained for Rh(I) complexation with L4-OCHPh2 evidenced the formation of both species (31P δ =121.3ppm, 1 J (103Rh–31P)=293Hz and 31P δ =132.3ppm, 1 J (103Rh–31P)=264Hz), with an approximate ratio of 5:1, respectively (Fig. 3A ). To further appraise the relative stability of Rh(I)/monophosphite complexes, the ligand L2-OBn, used as standard, was added to a CDCl3 solution of Rh(acac)(CO)(L4-OCHPh2). After 30min, a considerable ligand's exchange resulted in the formation of a ca. 1:0.6 mixture of [Rh(acac)(CO)(L4-OCHPh2)]/[Rh(acac)(CO)(L2-OBn)], in addition to the non-coordinated ligands L2-OBn and L4-OCHPh2, as demonstrated by 31P NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 3B), suggesting that [Rh(acac)(CO)(L2-OBn)] is more stable than [Rh(acac)(CO)(L4-OCHPh2)]. From these studies, we presume that the lower activity and selectivity obtained with Rh(I)/L4-OCHPh2 catalyst might be due to the exchange of L4-OCHPh2 by CO ligands in {RhH(CO)4-n L n } type complexes, leading to different Rh(I) catalytic species in solution, under hydroformylation conditions. On the other hand, the high steric hindrance around the metal centre exerted by the diphenylmethoxy groups (cone angle=271°) [29] might turn difficult the approach of the substrate's disubstituted CC double bond, leading to lower catalytic activity (Table 1, entry 4). Additional coordination studies were carried out in solution, using L2-OBn as model monophosphite ligand, to perform a deeper inspection on possibly formed Rh(I)/phosphite species. The addition of two or fivefold excess of L2-OBn, resulted in formation of the same two major and minor species, in a constant ratio (1:0.04), as shown by 31P NMR spectra, which remains practically unchanged, showing only an additional singlet at δ =132.5ppm, typical of the non-coordinated phosphite ligand (Fig. SI.25). This suggests that a Rh(I) species containing only one bulky phosphite ligand is formed, even in the presence of a large excess of L2-OBn, since the ligand's large cone angle might circumvent the coordination of a second monophosphite [18–21]. Furthermore, to appraise the effect of temperature on the complex coordination mode, 31P NMR spectra at variable temperatures (from 10°C to 50°C) were carried out using equimolar amounts of [Rh(acac)(CO)2] and L2-OBn, in CDCl3. We observed that the equilibrium between the major (δ =120.1ppm) and minor species (δ =130.1ppm) is only moderately affected in this range of temperatures, with their ratio varying from 1:0.01 (at 10°C) to 1:0.1 (at 50°C) (Fig. SI.26). In addition, when the complex formation reaction is performed using a threefold excess of ligand, in toluene, at 80°C (similar conditions to those used in incubation of hydroformylation experiments), only the major species is detected by 31P NMR, evidenced by a doublet at 120.1ppm, 1 J (103Rh-31P)=288Hz (Fig. SI.27). In sum, the formation of [Rh(acac)(CO)(L2-OBn)] complex is demonstrated by the 1 J (103Rh, 31P) coupling constant, typical of rhodium(I)/aryl monophosphite complexes [38–41]. Moreover, IR spectra revealed a single wave-number at 2004cm−1 (Fig. SI.28), which refers to the presence of just one terminal carbonyl ligand. This spectroscopic data was consistent with those of related Rh(I)/tris-aryl monophosphite complexes [38–41]. In addition, the formation of [Rh(acac)(CO)(L2-OBn)] species was further corroborated by HRMS (ESI) on the isolated complex, which confirmed the presence of a molecular ion containing only one carbonyl and a single monophosphite ligand coordinated ([M-acac]+ =1287.2882) (Fig. SI.19). Upon performing the complexation reaction in a HP NMR tube under syngas pressure, using similar conditions to those of catalytic experiments (Psyngas =36bar, L/Rh ratio=3.2, T =80°C, 1mL toluene-d8), the formation of two new species was observed after 24h. The 31P NMR spectrum showed the appearance of a singlet at δ =132.1ppm, typical of the free monophosphite ligand L2-OBn, and two new doublets centred at δ =114.5ppm (1 J (103Rh–31P)=213Hz) and at δ =108.4ppm (1 J (103Rh–31P)=207Hz) (Fig. 4A ), which were assigned to active catalytic Rh(I) species bearing a P-Rh mono-coordinated phosphite ligand in equatorial or axial positions. Under these conditions, the 1H NMR spectrum did not show any signal in the hydride region. However, by decreasing the temperature to −40°C, it was possible to observe a broad 1H NMR doublet, centred at −10.3ppm (2 J (31P–1H)=35Hz) (Fig. 4B), characteristic of rhodium(I)/phosphorus hydride species [39]. 3.3 Reaction’s scope—hydroformylation of hindered double bonds in natural products Taking advantage from the high activity and selectivity achieved with Rh(I)/monophosphite catalysts in hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate (1), and aiming at the challenge of promoting the hydroformylation of sterically hindered CC double bonds of natural products, Rh(I)/L2-OBn was selected as model catalytic system, to enlarge the method's scope to a range of differently substituted alkyl olefins, being applied to the hydroformylation of oleic acid methyl ester (4), containing a 1,2-disubstituted CC bond (similarly to the previous substrate), the terpenoid (−)-isopulegol benzyl ether (5), encompassing a geminal-disubstituted CC double bond and the Δ4-steroid derivative, 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene (6), having a cyclic and trisubstituted double bond with a prominent steric hindrance. The results are presented in Table 2. The Rh(I)/L2-OBn catalytic system was able to promote the hydroformylation of internal CC double bonds of methyl oleate (4), under the same moderate reaction conditions (60°C, 25bar CO/H2) used for methyl non-3-enoate (1), achieving a conversion of 99% in 24h, with a remarkably high chemoselectivity (98%) for aldehydes, without occurrence of CC double bond isomerization (Table 2, entry 1). These results are comparable to those obtained with Rh(I)/tris(o-tert-butylphenyl) phosphite catalyst, under similar conditions [42,43]. On the other hand, in absence of phosphite ligand, only 83% conversion was obtained in 24h, under the same syngas pressure and temperature, with 77% chemoselectivity for aldehydes (Table 2, entry 2). Therefore, the higher conversion and chemoselectivity obtained with Rh(I)/L2-OBn catalyst suggest that [RhH(CO)4-n (L2-OBn) n ] complexes might be predominantly operating as the active catalytic species. 1H NMR and GC-MS analysis pointed toward the formation of both C9 and C10-formyl aldehydes 7a and 7b, respectively (see SI). Attempts to determine the reaction's enantioselectivity were carried out, using chiral phase GC and HPLC techniques, but an appropriate enantiomer separation was not achieved. Considering the large interest in the functionalization of natural terpene derivatives with formyl groups [5,11], the studies were extended to the hydroformylation of (−)-isopulegol benzyl ether (5) whose synthesis was performed by etherification of (−)-isopulegol (see SI), in order to avoid parallel reactions between the formyl group with the hydroxyl functionality [44,45]. After optimization of reaction parameters [46], Rh-catalysed hydroformylation of 5 was performed at the most suitable conditions (80°C, 25bar CO/H2), using Rh(I)/(S)-L2-OBn catalyst. This catalytic system provided 99% conversion in 12h, with 95% of chemoselectivity for aldehydes 8a and 8b, in a diastereomeric ratio of 77:23 (Table 2, entry 3). In the absence of phosphite ligand, no conversion was observed after 12h with the unmodified rhodium(I) catalyst, under the same reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 4), which clearly evidence the monophosphite's decisive role on achieving an active catalytic species for hydroformylation of this 1,1-disubstituted alkyl olefin. Regarding hydroformylation of 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene (6), optimization studies were first performed on the effects of substrate/Rh ratio, temperature and monophosphite ligand on the catalytic activity and selectivity. As previously observed [10,34], the hydroformylation of this internal double bond required a substrate/Rh ratio of 50:1, to achieve significant conversion values. The reaction was initially carried out under the “standard” initial conditions of 60°C and 25bar CO/H2, using Rh(I)/(R)-L2-OBn as catalyst; however, only 41% conversion was obtained in 48h, while chemoselectivity for aldehydes was inferior to 40%. So, the reaction conditions presented in Table 2 (100°C, 25bar CO/H2) were then used, providing 95% conversion after 48h, with 86% chemoselectivity for aldehydes and 70% diastereoselectivity for 4β-formyl-17β-acetoxy-5β-androstane 9a (Table 2, entry 5). The exclusive formation of 4-formyl derivatives occurs as a result of the insertion of the aldehyde functionality into the less substituted carbon atom, avoiding the formation of a quaternary carbon centre, according to Keulemans’ rule [47]. In addition, this regioespecificity indicates that the reaction takes place by direct hydroformylation of Δ4-double bond and not through previous isomerisation. These results are consistent with those obtained using Rh(I)/tris(o-tert-butylphenyl) phosphite catalyst, under similar conditions (89% conversion, 85% chemoselectivity, 68% diastereoselectivity) [34]. On the other hand, no products were obtained under the same conditions, in the absence of monophosphite ligand (Table 2, entry 6). It is worth mentioning the high activity and selectivity obtained with Rh(I)/L2-OBn catalyst for performing the hydroformylation of sterically hindered alkyl olefins, which is comparable to the most efficient systems so far reported. 4 Conclusions This study provides the first example on the application of Rh(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite catalysts in the hydroformylation of highly substituted CC alkyl double bonds, showing that such catalytic systems can be tuned through the structural modulation of the ether substituents at the 2′-binaphthyl positions of the bulky phosphites. Indeed, the different OR groups were found to have a remarkable effect on catalytic activity and selectivity of the Rh(I)/phosphite complexes, in the hydroformylation of internal CC double bonds of methyl non-3-enoate, where Rh(I)/tris-2′-benzyloxy-1,1′-binaphthyl-2-yl]phosphite catalyst appears to be the most chemoselective for aldehydes. It has been further demonstrated that this catalyst was capable of high conversions and selectivity in the hydroformylation of 1,2-disubstituted internal CC double bonds of oleic acid methyl ester, 1,1-disubstituted double bonds of (−)-isopulegol benzyl ether and the Δ4-unsaturated steroid, 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene, under moderate reaction conditions. In sum, the results presented herein turn these Rh(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite catalytic systems into excellent candidates with great potential to promote the hydroformylation of a broad range of sterically demanding alkyl olefins, opening new perspectives regarding their functionalization for industrial preparation of either fine or bulk chemicals. coredata.dc:description: The hydroformylation of highly substituted alkyl olefins was efficiently performed, with use of rhodium(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite catalysts, containing different ether substituents at the 2′-binaphthyl position (OMe, OBn, OCHPh2 and OAdamantyl). A systematic kinetic study, carried out for hydroformylation of methyl non-3-enoate, has shown a significant influence of the ligand’s OR group in the performance of the rhodium catalysts, with Rh(I)/tris[2′-benzyloxy-1,1′-binaphthyl-2-yl]phosphite catalytic system (Rh(I)/L2-OBn) achieving the highest chemoselectivity for aldehydes, and regioselectivity for C-5 formyl products. This catalytic system was further applied to the hydroformylation of encumbered CC double bonds of natural products, namely oleic acid methyl ester, (−)-isopulegol benzyl ether and 17β-acetoxyandrost-4-ene, obtaining high catalytic activity, chemo-, regio- and diastereoselectivity, under relatively mild reaction conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient Rh(I)/tris-binaphthyl monophosphite catalysts for hydroformylation of sterically hindered alkyl olefins
